case_name: Union of India v. Balakrishna Flour Mills

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 568 of 1960 filed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 568 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment, and order dated April 6, 1956,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 6, 1956 of Madras High Court in O.S.A. No. 147 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment, and order dated April 6, 1956, of the Madras High Court in 0. S, A. No. 147 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 19, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-The point involved in this appeal

facts.text: Respondent imported quantity of oats from Australia described as standard feed-oats in whole grain.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent imported from Australia a quantity of oats which was described in the indent, companytract and shipping documents as standard feed-oats. The companymodity imported companysisted of oats in whole grain.

facts.text: Goods arrived in Madras on August 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The goods arrived in Madras on August 1, 1952 and when the respondent attempted to clear the goods,

facts.text: Import during period July to December 1952 under Import Trade Control Schedules.

anchor.surface_text: under the Import Trade Control Schedules current during the period July to December 1952 when the companysignment reached India.

facts.text: Respondent did not obtain import licence before placing order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who carried on business in fodder under the name and style of Balakrishna Flour Mills placed an order with an Australian firm for the supply of whole grain feed- oats without obtaining any licence for the import.

facts.text: Customs Authorities required production of licence to clear goods.

anchor.surface_text: the Customs Authorities insisted on the production of a licence before he would be permitted to do so.

facts.text: Assistant Collector held goods fall within item 32, no licence, contravention of s.19 Sea Customs Act read with s.3 Import Export Control Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector hold that. the goods imported fell within item 32 and as admittedly the respondent held numberlicence from the Deputy Chief Controller of Imports Exports, Madras companyering the import, there had been a companytravention of a. 19 of the Sea Customs Act read with s. 3 2  of the Import Export Control Act, 1947

facts.text: Assistant Collector directed confiscation of goods and imposed fine of Rs.5,000 in lieu of confiscation.

anchor.surface_text: and so proceeded to deal with the violation under s. 167  8  of the Sea Customs Act. He directed the companyfiscation of the good sand imposed a fine of Rs.5,000/- in lieu of companyfiscation,

facts.text: Appeal to Collector of Customs rejected.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed to the Collector of Customs was rejected and thereafter the respondent moved the High Court

facts.text: Respondent filed application for writ of mandamus under s.45 Specific Relief Act in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the respondent moved the High Court for the issue of a writ of mandamus under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act.

facts.text: Single Judge dismissed the application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the application dismissed it on the ground that the order of the Customs Authorities classifying uncrushed feeds-oats as grain and number as fodder companyld number be said to be either perverse or malafide

facts.text: Division Bench allowed appeal and issued direction prohibiting collection of fines and penalties.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was perferred therefrom to a Division Bench and the learned Judged allowed the appeal and issued a direction prohibiting the Collector and his subordinates from companylecting or taking steps to recover the fines and penalties imposed on the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside Division Bench order.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the Division Bench of the High Court set aside. The application filed by the respondent under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act will stand dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This Court proceeded on the basis that it is primarily for the Import Control authorities to determine the head or entry under which any particular commodity fell but that if in doing so, these authorities adopted a construction which no reasonable person could adopt i.e., if the construction was perverse then it was a case in which the Court was competent to interfere. In other words, if there were two constructions which an entry could reasonably bear, and one of them which was in favour of Revenue was adopted , the Court has no jurisdiction to interfere merely because the other interpretation favourable to the subject appeals to the Court as the better one to adopt.

concepts.interpretation: Court interferes only if administrative construction is perverse or one no reasonable person could adopt; defers to reasonable views even if another view possible

issues.text: The nature and extent of the jurisdiction possessed by the High Court in considering the validity of an order of the Customs Authorities interpreting the provisions of the entries in the Tariff Schedule as regards the imposition of duties

anchor.surface_text: certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1 e granted by the High, Court of Madras is a very short one and relates to the nature and extent of the jurisdiction possessed by the High Court in considering the validity of an order of the Customs Authorities interpreting the provisions of the entries in the Tariff Schedule as regards the imposition of duties.

issues.text: Whether the feed-oats fell within item 42 or within item 32 of the Import Trade Control Schedules

anchor.surface_text: under the Import Trade Control Schedules current during the period July to December 1952 when the consignment reached India. The controversy centered round the point whether the feed-oats fell within item 42 or within item 32 of the Circular.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Customs Authorities classifying uncrushed feed-oats as grain and not as fodder could be said to be either perverse or mala fide

issues.text: Whether the decision of the Customs authorities as regards the entry of the Tariff classification within which an imported commodity fell was final or open to judicial review and had ultimately to be decided by the Courts

anchor.surface_text: under Art.226 of the Constitution, and not as here under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act under which the power of the Court to interfere is certainly narrower and not wider. This Court proceeded on the basis that it is primarily for the Import Control authorities to determine the head or entry under which any particular commodity fell but that if in doing so, these authorities adopted a construction which no reasonable person could adopt i.e., if the construction was perverse then it was a case in which the Court was competent to interfere.

issues.answer: limited judicial review only if perverse

arguments.claim: s.45 Specific Relief Act narrower jurisdiction than Art.226

anchor.surface_text: That was a case where a party moved the High Court under Art.226 of the Constitution, and not as here under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act under which the power of the Court to interfere is certainly narrower and not wider.

holdings.text: The Court is competent to interfere with the classification decision of Customs authorities only if they adopted a construction which no reasonable person could adopt, i.e., if the construction was perverse.

anchor.surface_text: This Court proceeded on the basis that it is primarily for the Import Control authorities to determine the head or entry under which any particular commodity fell but that if in doing so, these authorities adopted a construction which no reasonable person could adopt i.e., if the construction was perverse then it was a case in which the Court was competent to interfere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primarily for authorities to classify; court defers unless perverse, following Venkateswaram v. Wadhwani precedent.

holdings.text: The power to interfere under s.45 Specific Relief Act is narrower than under Art.226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: That was a case where a party moved the High Court under Art.226 of the Constitution, and not as here under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act under which the power of the Court to interfere is certainly narrower and not wider.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior case under constitutional writ jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The decision of Customs authorities classifying the oats under item 32 could not be said to be a view which on no reasonable interpretation could be entertained; it was rationally supportable.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, if there were two constructions which an entry could reasonably bear, and one of them which was in favour of Revenue was adopted , the Court has no jurisdiction to interfere merely because the other interpretation favourable to the subject appeals to the Court as the better one to adopt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two possible constructions; revenue's reasonable view adopted, not perverse.

holdings.text: The matter is placed beyond controversy by the specific reference to oats in entry 32 where grain is classified into two categories: oats and other grains.

anchor.surface_text: In this particular case however, the matter is placed beyond the pale of controversy by the specific reference to oats in entry 32 where grain is classified into two categories oats and other. grains.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific entry prevails; High Court overlooked full entry.

holdings.text: Even absent specific reference to oats, a particular species of grain cannot be excluded from item 32 merely because capable of use as cattle or horse feed; such grain does not become fodder.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the conclusion or decision of the Customs authorities was rationally supportable. We consider that even if there was no specific reference to oats in entry 32, any particular species of grain cannot be excluded merely because it is capable of being used as cattle or horse feed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification by nature of commodity, not use; oats capable of human consumption; fodder defined as dried food for stall-feeding cattle.

holdings.text: The authorities could properly take into account whether respondent was misled by prior advice in modifying quantum of penalty imposed.

anchor.surface_text: We are drawing attention to this matter merely for pointing out that it is a matter which the authorities could properly take into account in modifying, if they consider that the respondent has really been misled, the quantum of penalty imposed on the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No finding on receipt of clarification letter; obiter suggestion for penalty mitigation.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the limits of the jurisdiction of the Court it is sufficient to refer to the decision in Venkatesvaram v. Wadhwani. 1 That was a case where a party moved the High Court under Art.226 of the Constitution, and not as here under s. 45 of the Specific Relief Act under which the power of the Court to interfere is certainly narrower and not wider. This Court proceeded on the basis that it is primarily for the Import Control authorities to determine the head or entry under which any particular commodity fell but that if in doing so, these authorities adopted a construction which no reasonable person could adopt i.e., if the construction was perverse then it was a case in which the Court was competent to interfere.

precedents.cited_proposition: Primarily for Import Control authorities to determine classification of imported goods under tariff entries; courts can interfere only if the construction adopted is perverse (no reasonable person could adopt it); if two reasonable constructions possible, court cannot interfere if revenue-favourable one is chosen

anchor.surface_text: The word fodder is defined in the Oxford dictionary as dried food, hay, straw etc. for stall feeding Cattle. Without resorting to A.I.R. 1961 S.C. 1506, Johnsons famous definition of oats in his Dictionary, it is sufficient to point out that oats, though they may serve as food for horses, is also used as human food in other words it is not by its nature or characteristic capable of serving solely as food for animal, and incapable of use in the human dietary.
The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the Division Bench of the High Court set aside. The application filed by the respondent under s. 45 of
